All Words Index for All

abandon

[ə'bændən], [ə'bændən]


Image Search
v. 放弃；抛弃；放纵
n. 放纵
cease to support or look after (someone); desert.
leave (a place or vehicle) empty or uninhabited, without intending to return.
condemn someone or something to (a specified fate) by ceasing to take an interest in or look after them.
give up completely (a course of action, a practice, or a way of thinking).
discontinue (a scheduled event) before completion.
allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse).
complete lack of inhibition or restraint.
"her natural mother had abandoned her at an early age"
"derelict houses were abandoned"
"it was an attempt to persuade businesses not to abandon the area to inner-city deprivation"
"he had clearly abandoned all pretense of trying to succeed"
"against the background of perceived threats, the tour was abandoned"
"abandoning herself to moony fantasies"
"she sings and sways with total abandon"
Those who abandon themselves to despair can not succeed.那些自暴自弃的人无法成功。
Despite some difficulties, they're not going to abandon the plan.尽管他们遇到了一些困难,但并不打算放弃这个计划。
The cruel man abandoned his wife and child.那个狠心的男人抛弃了他的妻儿。
They abandon themselves to drinking.他们沉湎于饮酒。
He signed cheques with careless abandon.他无所顾忌地乱开支票。
The cheerleader waved his arms with wild abandon.拉拉队队长疯狂地挥舞双臂。

abattoir

['æbətwɑː(r)], ['æbətwɑːr]


Image Search
n. 屠宰场；角斗场
a slaughterhouse.
All that talk about abattoirs turned me right off.关於屠宰场的那些话让我十分恶心。
The lambs are taken to the local abattoir to be slaughtered.这些羊运到当地的屠宰场宰杀。
Finally, Mark Symmers has the opportunity and crown prince finally face-to-face stands in Luo Macheng's big abattoir, carries on a life and death duel.最后，马克西默斯终于有机会与太子面对面地站在罗马城的大角斗场上，进行一场生死决斗。

abbreviation

[əˌbriːvi'eɪʃn], [əˌbriːvi'eɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 缩写
a shortened form of a word or phrase.
the process or result of abbreviating.
All abbreviations are to be written out.所有的缩写都要完整地写出来
UK is the abbreviation of the United Kingdom.UK是大不列颠联合王国的缩写。
English abbreviation is seen everywhere now.英语缩略语的使用已遍及社会生活的各个领域。

abdicate

['æbdɪkeɪt], ['æbdɪkeɪt]


Image Search
vt. 正式放弃；让位
vi. 退位；辞职
(of a monarch) renounce one's throne.
fail to fulfill or undertake (a responsibility or duty).
"in 1918 Kaiser Wilhelm abdicated as German emperor"
"the government was accused of abdicating its responsibility"
He was forced to abdicate his claim on the property.他被迫放弃要求财产的权利。
He's abdicated all responsibility in the affair.他已经放弃了这件事中的一切职责。
The king was forced to abdicate his throne.国王被迫逊位。
King Edward VIII abdicated in 1936.英王爱德华八世于1936年退位。
I want to try something different so I abdicate the office.我辞职是因为我想尝试些不一样的东西。

abduct

[æb'dʌkt], [æb'dʌkt]


Image Search
vt. 诱拐；绑走
take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
(of a muscle) move (a limb or part) away from the midline of the body or from another part.
"the millionaire who disappeared may have been abducted"
He had attempted to abduct the two children.他曾企图诱拐这两名儿童。
I can say you abduct a high school student.我可以告你诱拐中学生。

abhor

[əb'hɔː(r)], [əb'hɔːr]


Image Search
vt. 憎恶；厌恶；痛恨
regard with disgust and hatred.
"professional tax preparers abhor a flat tax because it would dry up their business"
They abhor all forms of racial discrimination.他们憎恶任何形式的种族歧视。
Most people abhor cruelyt to children.大部分人憎恶虐待儿童。
I abhor every commonplace phrase by which wit is intended.我厌恶所有那些力图表现智慧的陈腐不堪的俗话。
I will put my dwelling place among you, and I will not abhor you.我要在你们中间立我的帐幕，我的心也不厌恶你们。
Most people abhor cruelty to children.大多数人痛恨虐待儿童。
Spitting in the street is a practice that I abhor.我痛恨随地吐痰这种习惯。

abolish

[ə'bɒlɪʃ], [ə'bɑːlɪʃ]


Image Search
vt. 废除；革除；消灭
formally put an end to (a system, practice, or institution).
"the tax was abolished in 1977"
Abraham Lincoln abolished slavery in the United States.亚伯拉罕·林肯在美国废除了奴隶制。
There are many bad customs and laws that ought to be abolished.有许多不良的习俗和法规应予以废除。
They petitioned the government to abolish hanging.他们向政府请愿，要求废除绞刑。
The legislature passed a law to abolish the surtax.立法机关通过了一项废除附加税的法令。
The weapons of war must be abolished before they abolish us.在作战武器消灭我们以前，我们应先把它消灭。

abominable

[ə'bɒmɪnəbl], [ə'bɑːmɪnəbl]


Image Search
adj. 讨厌的；令人憎恶的；糟糕的
causing moral revulsion.
very bad or unpleasant.
"the uprising was suppressed with abominable cruelty"
"a cup of abominable tea"
Your behaviour is abominable to me.我讨厌你的行为.
Murder is the most abominable crime.凶杀是最可恶的犯罪。
The food in the cafeteria is abominable.这家自助餐厅的膳食糟糕透了。

abrupt

[ə'brʌpt], [ə'brʌpt]


Image Search
adj. 突然的；唐突的；意外的；陡峭的
sudden and unexpected.
brief to the point of rudeness; curt.
(of a style of speech or writing) not flowing smoothly; disjointed.
steep; precipitous.
"I was surprised by the abrupt change of subject"
"you were rather abrupt with that young man"
"the abrupt double peak of the mountain"
The river takes an abrupt bend to the west.这河突然向西转弯。
His speech comes to an abrupt stop.他的演讲突然停止了。
That young man has an abrupt manner.那个年轻人态度很无礼。
His manner of speaking was quite abrupt.他的说话方式很唐突。
Pug's abrupt proposal gave her a big surprise.帕格的出乎意料的求婚给了她一个意外的惊喜。
We walked down an abrupt slope.我们沿着陡峭的斜坡走下来。
I haven't seen such abrupt rocks yet.你至今没看到过这样陡峭的岩石。

abstain

[əb'steɪn], [əb'steɪn]


Image Search
v. 戒绝；弃权；节制
restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
refrain from drinking alcohol.
formally decline to vote either for or against a proposal or motion.
"abstaining from chocolate"
"most pregnant women abstain or drink very little"
"forty-one voted with the opposition, and some sixty more abstained"
He swore to abstain from smoking.他发誓要戒烟。
A high percentage of women said they had abstained from alcohol during pregnancy.很大比例的妇女称他们在怀孕期间戒了酒。
I abstained from voting.我弃权不投票。
Six countries voted for the change, five voted against, and two abstained.六个国家投票赞成改变，五个反对，还有两个弃权。
He abstained from speaking at the meeting.会上，他默不作声。

abstract

['æbstrækt], ['æbstrækt]


Image Search
existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence.
dealing with ideas rather than events.
not based on a particular instance; theoretical.
(of a word, especially a noun) denoting an idea, quality, or state rather than a concrete object.
relating to abstract art.
consider (something) theoretically or separately from something else.
extract or remove (something).
used euphemistically to say that someone has stolen something.
withdraw.
make a written summary of (an article or book).
a summary of the contents of a book, article, or formal speech.
an abstract work of art.
that which is abstract; the theoretical consideration of something.
"abstract concepts such as love or beauty"
"the novel was too abstract and esoteric to sustain much attention"
"we have been discussing the problem in a very abstract manner"
"abstract words like truth or equality"
"abstract pictures that look like commercial color charts"
"to abstract science and religion from their historical context can lead to anachronism"
"applications to abstract more water from streams"
"his pockets contained all he had been able to abstract from the apartment"
"as our relationship deepened you seemed to abstract yourself"
"staff who index and abstract material for an online database"
"an abstract of his inaugural address"
"a big unframed abstract"
"the abstract must be made concrete by examples"
We may talk of beautiful things, but beauty itself is abstract.我们尽可谈论美的事物，然而美本身却是抽象的。
He has some abstract notion of wanting to change the world.他有一种要改造世界的空想。
Abstract paintings did not appeal to him.抽象派绘画引不起他的兴趣。
The whole text of the abstract shall contain not more than 300 Chinese characters.摘要文字部分不得超过300个字。
She abstracted the main points from the argument.她把论据概括成要点。
They are trying to abstract iron from ore.他们正试图从矿石中提取铁。
There is a plan to abstract 8 million gallons of water from the river.有一个从这条河中抽取800万加仑水的计划。
She tried to abstract my attention from my work.她企图转移我对工作的注意力。

absurd

[əb'sɜːd], [əb'sɜːrd]


Image Search
adj. 荒唐的；可笑的；不合理的
n. 荒唐
wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate.
arousing amusement or derision; ridiculous.
"the allegations are patently absurd"
"gym shorts and knee socks looked absurd on such a tall girl"
He finally recovered from an absurd infatuation.他终于从荒唐的迷恋中醒悟过来。
What an absurd suggestion!多荒谬的建议啊！
We have no intention of lying down under these absurd allegations.对这些荒谬的指控我们是不甘受辱的。
It was absurd of you to suggest such a thing.你居然建议这样的事，太可笑了。
He looked absurd in that get-up.他穿著那套衣服看上去怪模怪样的。
It is absurd to argue from these premises.凭这些前提议论是不合理的。
The proposal borders on the absurd.该提议近乎可笑。
The pleading with Nora is beyond absurd.向诺拉好言相求真是荒唐得无以复加。

abundant

[ə'bʌndənt], [ə'bʌndənt]


Image Search
adj. 丰富的；充裕的
existing or available in large quantities; plentiful.
having plenty of something.
"there was abundant evidence to support the theory"
"the riverbanks were abundant in wild plants"
Indonesia is abundant in petroleum deposits.印尼的石油蕴藏量丰富。
The agricultural commodities are abundant this year.今年的农产品很丰富。
Birds concentrate in places where food is abundant.鸟聚集在食物丰盛的地方。
There is abundant firewood in the forest.森林里有充裕的薪柴可用。
We have abundant oil seeds to sell.我们有充裕的油籽出售。

abuse

[ə'bjuːs], [ə'bjuːs]


Image Search
n. 滥用；恶习
vt. 滥用；辱骂；虐待
use (something) to bad effect or for a bad purpose; misuse.
make excessive and habitual use of (alcohol or drugs, especially illegal ones).
treat (a person or an animal) with cruelty or violence, especially regularly or repeatedly.
assault (someone, especially a woman or child) sexually.
masturbate.
use or treat in such a way as to cause damage or harm.
speak in an insulting and offensive way to or about (someone).
the improper use of something.
unjust or corrupt practice.
cruel and violent treatment of a person or animal.
violent treatment involving sexual assault, especially on a repeated basis.
insulting and offensive language.
"the judge abused his power by imposing the fines"
"riders who abuse their horses should be prosecuted"
"he was a depraved man who had abused his two young daughters"
"he had been abusing his body for years"
"the referee was abused by players from both teams"
"alcohol abuse"
"protection against fraud and abuse"
"a black eye and other signs of physical abuse"
"young people who have suffered sexual abuse"
"waving his fists and hurling abuse at the driver"
The government has set up a working party to look into the problem of drug abuse.政府已成立工作组调查滥用毒品问题。
His political reputation was tainted by his abuse of the power.他因滥用职权而破坏了政治声誉。
He greeted me with a stream of abuse.他见到我就连声辱骂。
It's easy to abuse one's power.人容易滥用权力。
I don't consider it good for a person to be afraid of being abused.一个人怕挨骂,我看不好。
He abused his wife and children.他虐待他的妻子和孩子。

abyss

[ə'bɪs], [ə'bɪs]


Image Search
n. 深渊；无底洞
a deep or seemingly bottomless chasm.
a wide or profound difference between people; a gulf.
the regions of hell conceived of as a bottomless pit.
a catastrophic situation seen as likely to occur.
"a rope led down into the dark abyss"
"the abyss between the two nations"
"Satan's dark abyss"
"teetering on the edge of the abyss of a total political wipeout"
He has been in the abyss of despair.他已陷入绝望的深渊。
I've entered the Abyss and never returned.我进去了深渊，再也没回来。
S. is now censured and condemned by the people in every region and country of the world and finding itself in the abyss of international isolation and ruin.目前，美帝国主义在全世界所有的地区和国家都受到孤立和谴责，并且发现自身已处在国际孤立和毁灭的无底洞里。

academic

[ˌækə'demɪk], [ˌækə'demɪk]


Image Search
adj. 学院的；学术的；理论的
n. 大学教师，大学生；学者，学究
relating to education and scholarship.
relating to an educational or scholarly institution or environment.
(of an institution or a course of study) placing a greater emphasis on reading and study than on technical or practical work.
(of a person) interested in or excelling at scholarly pursuits and activities.
(of an art form) conventional, especially in an idealized or excessively formal way.
not of practical relevance; of only theoretical interest.
a teacher or scholar in a college or institute of higher education.
"academic achievement"
"students resplendent in academic dress"
"an academic high school that prepares students for the best colleges and universities"
"Ben is not an academic child but he tries hard"
"academic painting"
"the debate has been largely academic"
Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema was an English painter in the academic tradition.阿尔玛·台德玛是学院派的英国画家。
With my strong academic background, I am competent.依我良好的学术背景,我能胜任。
Applicant must possess good conduct and obtain satisfactory academic results.申请者必须拥有良好品性,并考获令人满意的成绩;
During the past four years I have had a good deal of academic experience in communications technology.四年来,我掌握了丰富的通信技术上的理论知识。

access

['ækses], ['ækses]


Image Search
n. 入口；通道
n. 接近(的机会)；使用之权
vt. 进入；(电脑)存取
a means of approaching or entering a place.
the right or opportunity to use or benefit from something.
the right or opportunity to approach or see someone.
the action or process of obtaining or retrieving information stored in a computer's memory.
denoting noncommercial broadcasting produced by local independent groups, rather than by professionals.
an attack or outburst of an emotion.
approach or enter (a place).
obtain, examine, or retrieve (data or a file).
"the staircase gives access to the top floor"
"do you have access to a computer?"
"we were denied access to our grandson"
"this prevents unauthorized access or inadvertent deletion of the file"
"public-access television"
"I was suddenly overcome with an access of rage"
"single rooms have private baths accessed via the balcony"
This is the only means of access to the building.这是进入这栋楼的唯一入口。
The avalanche cut off the access to the mountain village.雪崩切断了进入山村的通道。
The only access to that building is along the track.到那座大楼的唯一通道就是沿这条小路走。
Only high officials have access to the president.只有高级官员才可以接近总统。
People in that mountain area had no access to education.那个山区的人们过去没有受教育的机会。
I demanded access to a telephone.我要求有权使用电话。
Students have full access to all resources.学生对所有资源有完全访问权。
An error occurred when we tried to access the inventory database.当我们试图进入存货数据库时，屏幕上显示出现了错误。
We can't access the Internet.我们连不上网。
She access three different files to find the correct information.她存取了三个文件以找寻所要的信息。
Branch officials can access the central data bank.分行官员可以存取中央数据库。

acclaimed

[ək'leɪmd], [ək'leɪmd]


Image Search
adj. 受赞誉的，受人欢迎的
v. 动词acclaim的过去式、过去分词
praise enthusiastically and publicly.
"the conference was acclaimed as a considerable success"

accommodate

[ə'kɒmədeɪt], [ə'kɑːmədeɪt]


Image Search
vt. 供给住宿；使适应；容纳；提供；顾及；调解
vi. 适应；调节
(of physical space, especially a building) provide lodging or sufficient space for.
fit in with the wishes or needs of.
adapt to.
"the cabins accommodate up to 6 people"
"any language must accommodate new concepts"
"making consumers accommodate to the realities of today's marketplace"
This hotel can accommodate up to 500 guests.这旅馆可供500位来宾住宿。
We must accommodate ourselves to circumstances.我们必须适应环境。
One flat can accommodate a family of five.一套单元房可容纳一个五口之家。
The bank is accommodating its customers more than it used to.这家银行现在给客户贷款比以前多了。
The government came up with a new economic proposal that accommodates the special needs and interests of the elderly.政府出台了一项新的考虑老年人特殊要求和利益的新经济提案。
He tried to accommodate the dispute between his two friends.他尽力调解两个朋友之间的纠纷。
Her eyes took a while to accommodate to the darkness.过了一会儿，她的眼睛才能适应黑暗。

accommodation

[əˌkɒmə'deɪʃn], [əˌkɑːmə'deɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 膳宿；和解；住处；适应
a room, group of rooms, or building in which someone may live or stay.
lodging; room and board.
the available space for occupants in a building, vehicle, or vessel.
the provision of a room or lodging.
a convenient arrangement; a settlement or compromise.
the process of adapting or adjusting to someone or something.
the automatic adjustment of the focus of the eye by flattening or thickening of the lens.
"the cost includes airfare and hotel accommodations"
"the company offers a number of guesthouse accommodations in Cape Cod"
"there was lifeboat accommodation for 1,178 people"
"the building is used exclusively for the accommodation of guests"
"management was seeking an accommodation with labor"
"accommodation to a separate political entity was not possible"
There travelling students found accommodation at moderate terms.旅游的学生们感到那儿的膳宿费是公道的。
If labour and management don't reach an accommodation there will be a strike.如果劳资双方达不成妥协，就会发生罢工。
We can provide accommodation for six people at a push.如情况需要，我们可以安排六个人的住处。
Hotel accommodation was scarce during the Olympic Games.奥运会期间，旅馆房间很难找。
I will arrange the accommodation of my plans to yours.我将调整我的计划以便和你的计划相适应。
Their spirits had learned accommodation to much more than cold.他们的心灵已经适应于比寒冷更坏得多的条件。

accompanied

[ə'kʌmpəni], [ə'kʌmpəni]


Image Search
vt. 陪伴；伴随...发生；补充；给 ... 伴奏
vi. 伴奏
go somewhere with (someone) as a companion or escort.
be present or occur at the same time as (something else).
provide (something) as a complement or addition to something else.
play a musical accompaniment for.
"the two sisters were to accompany us to New York"
"the illness is often accompanied by nausea"
"home-cooked ham accompanied by brown bread"
She asked me to accompany her to the airport.她要求我陪她到机场去。
Lightning usually accompanies thunder.闪电通常伴有雷声。
The text is accompanied by illustration.正文附有插图。
The singer was accompanied on the piano by her sister.女歌手由她姐姐钢琴伴奏。
In the singer's eyes,she accompanied magnificently.在那名歌手的眼里,她伴奏得精彩极了。

accord

[ə'kɔːd], [ə'kɔːrd]


Image Search
n. 协议；一致；符合
v. 与...一致；给予；调解
give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition).
(of a concept or fact) be harmonious or consistent with.
an official agreement or treaty.
agreement or harmony.
"the powers accorded to the head of state"
"the government and the rebels are in accord on one point"
The two countries reached an accord.两国签订了一项协议。
His words are in accord with his ideas.他心口一致。
Their views were found to be in perfect accord.人们发现他们的意见是完全一致的。
Your behavior is not in accord with your principle.你的行为与你的原则不符。
Our information does not accord with his reports.我们所了解的情况与他的报告不一致。
He was accorded a warm welcome.他受到热烈的欢迎。
We should accord the President the proper deference.我们应给予总统恰当的尊重.
The mayor will try to accord the controversy over the housing scheme.市长试图调解住房规划方面的争议。

accreditation

[əˌkredɪ'teɪʃn], [əˌkredɪ'teɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 认证；委派
the action or process of officially recognizing someone as havinɡ a particular status or beinɡ qualified to perform a particular activity.
official certification that a school or course has met standards set by external regulators.
an acknowledgment of a person's responsibility for or achievement of something.
"the accreditation of professionals"
"the first fully online university to receive national accreditation"
"both parties create authorship, and to make this clear I have always used joint accreditations"
In case of replacement, the accreditation of the player replaced will be cancelled.若出现顶替现象,被替换运动员的认证卡将被取消。
US schools generally announce their accreditation in admission brochures.通常,美国大学会在招生简章中声明自己的认证情况。
How can you tell if a school has accreditation or not?那么,你又如何知道一所学校是不是受到认证了呢?
I told the school owner how serious this could be since the accreditation delegation is coming.于是，我对校长提了这件事情的严重性，因为认证代表团就要来了。
He carried a letter of accreditation.他带了一份委派书。

accumulate

[ə'kjuːmjəleɪt], [ə'kjuːmjəleɪt]


Image Search
v. 积累；增加；聚集
gather together or acquire an increasing number or quantity of.
gradually gather or acquire (a resulting whole).
gather or build up.
"investigators have yet to accumulate enough evidence"
"her goal was to accumulate a huge fortune"
"the toxin accumulated in their bodies"
They set out to accumulate a huge mass of data.他们开始积累大量的资料。
Dust and dirt soon accumulates if a house is not cleaned regularly.房屋不经常打扫,尘土很快就越积越多。
True poetry accumulates meaning every time it is read.真正好诗愈念涵义愈丰富。
However, as the evidence began to accumulate, experts from the zoo felt obliged to investigate.然而，当证据日趋增多时，该动物园的专家们感到有必要进行调查。
Over the years, I had accumulated hundreds of books.多年来,我收集了几百本书。

accumulation

[əˌkjuːmjə'leɪʃn], [əˌkjuːmjə'leɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 积聚；累积；积聚物
the acquisition or gradual gathering of something.
a mass or quantity of something that has gradually gathered or been acquired.
"the accumulation of wealth"
"the accumulation of paperwork on her desk"
Accumulation of excess fluid within the interstitial spaces.过多的液体在体腔内积聚又称为积水。
The puzzle appears greater when one recalls the vast accumulation of material power available to the Habsburgs.回想一下哈布斯堡家族所能积聚和掌握的大量物质力量就更令人困惑费解。
Each of us is the accumulation of our memories.我们每个人都是我们记忆的累积。
The steady accumulation of small debts was a ball and chain to his progress.不断累积的小债务妨碍了他的发展不断累积的小债务妨碍了他的发展。

accurate

['ækjərət], ['ækjərət]


Image Search
adj. 准确的；精确的
(of information, measurements, statistics, etc.) correct in all details; exact.
(of an instrument or method) capable of giving accurate information.
faithfully or fairly representing the truth about someone or something.
(with reference to a weapon, missile, or shot) capable of or successful in reaching the intended target.
"accurate information about the illness is essential"
"an accurate thermometer"
"the portrait is an accurate likeness of Mozart"
"reliable, accurate rifles"
Hearsay definitely can't be regarded as accurate information.道听途说的决然不能算作很准确的消息。
The manager impressed on his office staff the importance of keeping accurate records.经理让办公室职员认识到做精确记录的重要性。

achieve

[ə'tʃiːv], [ə'tʃiːv]


Image Search
v. 完成；达到；实现
successfully bring about or reach (a desired objective, level, or result) by effort, skill, or courage.
"he achieved his ambition to become a journalist"
I've achieved only half of what I'd hoped to do.我希望做到的,我仅完成了一半。
Work hard, and you will achieve your goal.好好干,你就会达到自己的目标。
You will achieve your ambition if you work hard.如果你努力, 你的抱负是可以实现的。

achievement

[ə'tʃiːvmənt], [ə'tʃiːvmənt]


Image Search
n. 成就；成绩；完成；达到
a thing done successfully, typically by effort, courage, or skill.
the process or fact of achieving something.
a representation of a coat of arms with all the adjuncts to which a bearer of arms is entitled.
"to reach this stage is a great achievement"
"the achievement of professional recognition"
Effort and achievement are always in full accord.努力和成就总是相辅相承的。
You haven't realized the magnitude of her achievement.你没有认识到她这一成就的重大意义。
I felt a great sense of achievement when I reached the top of the mountain.当我到达山顶的时候，我有一种巨大的成就感。
Coming top in the exam was quite an achievement.考第一是很了不起的成绩。
Flying across the Atlantic for the first time was a great achievement.首次飞跃大西洋是一项了不起的业绩。
That task is impossible of achievement.那项任务不可能完成。
Most achievement rates were close to,or reached,100 per cent.就大部分的服务目标而言，该署几乎完全达到目标。
The achievement of this level of investment in a democratic nation is remarkable.在一个民主国家中投资达到这种高水平，是十分突出的。

acknowledge

[ək'nɒlɪdʒ], [ək'nɑːlɪdʒ]


Image Search
vt. 承认；告知收到；公认；表示感谢；注意到
accept or admit the existence or truth of.
(of a body of opinion) recognize the fact or importance or quality of.
express or display gratitude for or appreciation of.
accept the validity or legitimacy of.
show that one has noticed or recognized (someone) by making a gesture or greeting.
confirm (receipt of something).
"the plight of the refugees was acknowledged by the authorities"
"the art world has begun to acknowledge his genius"
"he received a letter acknowledging his services"
"Henry acknowledged Richard as his heir"
"she refused to acknowledge my presence"
We acknowledged the need for reform.我们承认改革的需要。
Please acknowledge this cheque as soon as you receive it.收到该支票后,请立即告知。
We hope you can acknowledge your mistake in public.希望你当众认错。
We are sending you some money in acknowledgement of your valuable help.我们送些酬劳，对您的大力协助聊表谢意。
I met him in town but he didn't even acknowledge me我在城里见到他，但他却把我当成素不相识的人乙

acknowledged

[ək'nɒlɪdʒd], [ək'nɒlɪdʒd]


Image Search
adj. 公认的，得到普遍认可的
v. 承认，认可；告知收到（动词acknowledge的过去式和过去分词）
recognized as being good or important.
accepted as valid or legitimate.
accept or admit the existence or truth of.
(of a body of opinion) recognize the fact or importance or quality of.
express or display gratitude for or appreciation of.
accept the validity or legitimacy of.
show that one has noticed or recognized (someone) by making a gesture or greeting.
confirm (receipt of something).
"he's an acknowledged expert in the field"
"an acknowledged brand leader"
"the plight of the refugees was acknowledged by the authorities"
"the art world has begun to acknowledge his genius"
"he received a letter acknowledging his services"
"Henry acknowledged Richard as his heir"
"she refused to acknowledge my presence"
He was generally acknowledged to be the finest poet in the land.他是公认的全国最优秀的诗人。
His rare gifts and bold strategy are universally acknowledged.他的雄才大略是举世公认的。
He acknowledged it as true.他承认它是真实的。
He acknowledged that the accident was due to his negligence.他承认事故的发生是因为他的疏忽。

acquire

[ə'kwaɪə(r)], [ə'kwaɪər]


Image Search
vt. 获得；学到；取得
buy or obtain (an object or asset) for oneself.
learn or develop (a skill, habit, or quality).
achieve (a particular reputation) as a result of one's behavior or activities.
"you must acquire the rudiments of Greek"
We should try to acquire good habits.我们应该努力养成良好的习惯。
He will acquire the right to permanent residency here.他将获得这里的永久居留权。
We hope to acquire the knowledge in the happiness.我们希望在快乐中获得知识。
One can never acquire enough experience.经验是永远学不足的。
You must acquire great skills of perception.你必须学会洞察事物的高超技巧。
We should acquire more firsthand information.我们应当取得更多的第一手资料。

acquisition

[ˌækwɪ'zɪʃn], [ˌækwɪ'zɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 获得；所获之物；采集
an asset or object bought or obtained, typically by a library or museum.
an act of purchase of one company by another.
buying or obtaining an asset or object.
the learning or developing of a skill, habit, or quality.
"there were many acquisitions among travel agents"
"Western culture places a high value on material acquisition"
"the acquisition of management skills"
Life is a process about the acquisition of knowledge, wealth and happiness.生命就是一个获得知识、财富和幸福的过程。
My classmates were attracted by the library's most recent acquisitions.同学们都被图书馆最近新添的书籍吸引了。

acquit

[ə'kwɪt], [ə'kwɪt]


Image Search
v. 宣布无罪；开释；原谅；表现
free (someone) from a criminal charge by a verdict of not guilty.
conduct oneself or perform in a specified way.
discharge (a duty or responsibility).
"she was acquitted on all counts"
"all the young women in the contest acquitted themselves well"
"they acquitted themselves of their charge with vigilance"
He was acquitted of the crime.他被宣告无罪。
They tried to bribe the judge to acquit them.他们试图贿赂法官判他们无罪。
Will the court acquit him of the crime?法庭会宣判他无罪释放吗?
I acquit Edward of all essential misconduct.我原谅爱德华的所有根本过错。
He acquitted himself like a hero.他表现得像个英雄。

activate

['æktɪveɪt], ['æktɪveɪt]


Image Search
v. 激活；使活动；起动
make (something) active or operative.
convert (a substance, molecule, etc.) into a reactive form.
"fumes from cooking are enough to activate the alarm"
"activated chlorine"
You can activate the system by buttons or voice recognition.你可以通过按钮或者声音识别来激活系统。
The burglar alarm was activated by mistake.防盗铃误响了。
I think if you flip the blue switch near the bottom it will activate the air conditioner.我想，如果你把下方的蓝色开关轻轻地推上，冷气就会出来了。
These push buttons can activate the elevator.这些按钮能启动电梯。

acute

[ə'kjuːt], [ə'kjuːt]


Image Search
adj. 严重的；敏锐的；急性的；剧烈的
(of a bad, difficult, or unwelcome situation or phenomenon) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree.
(of a disease or its symptoms) of short duration but typically severe.
denoting or designed for patients with acute conditions.
having or showing a perceptive understanding or insight: shrewd.
(of a physical sense or faculty) highly developed; keen.
(of an angle) less than 90°.
having a sharp end; pointed.
(of a sound) high; shrill.
short for acute accent.
"an acute housing shortage"
"acute appendicitis"
"acute hospital services"
"an acute awareness of changing fashions"
"an acute sense of smell"
He suffers from acute depression.他患有严重的抑郁症。
This area has an acute shortage of water.这个地方缺水严重。
She has acute hearing.她有很敏锐的听力。
The doctor said that you had acute appendicitis.医生说您患的是急性阑尾炎。
The patient is complaining of acute earache.病人说耳部剧痛。

adamant

['ædəmənt], ['ædəmənt]


Image Search
adj. 坚定不移的；固执的
n. 坚硬无比之物；硬石
refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
a legendary rock or mineral to which many, often contradictory, properties were attributed, formerly associated with diamond or lodestone.
"he is adamant that he is not going to resign"
She was quite adamant that she would not come.她坚决不来。
On this point I am adamant.在这一点上我是坚定不移的。
She was adamant in refusing to comply with his wishes.她固执地拒绝按他的意愿办。
She became as rigid as adamant.她变得如顽石般的固执。

adapt

[ə'dæpt], [ə'dæpt]


Image Search
vt. 改编；使适应
vi. 适应；适合
make (something) suitable for a new use or purpose; modify.
become adjusted to new conditions.
alter (a text) to make it suitable for filming, broadcasting, or the stage.
"hospitals have had to be adapted for modern medical practice"
"a large organization can be slow to adapt to change"
"the miniseries was adapted from Wouk's novel"
This novel has been adapted for radio from the Russian original.这部小说已由俄文原著改编成无线电广播节目。
She adapted herself quickly to the new climate.她很快就适应了这种新气候。
You must adapt to the norms of the society you live in.在社会中生活就要遵循社会行为准则。
It's hard to adapt this novel for children.要将这部小说改编为适合小孩的阅读水准很难。
There will be more than one person who can adapt to you.世界上适合你的人不会只有一个。

adaptable

[ə'dæptəbl], [ə'dæptəbl]


Image Search
adj. 能适应的；适应性强的；可改编的
able to adjust to new conditions.
able to be modified for a new use or purpose.
"rats are highly adaptable to change"
"a workforce with adaptable skills"
Any coupling device must be adaptable to obtain reasonable performance in all expected situations.所有联结设备在所有期望的情况一定是能适应的得到合理的表现。
The adaptable Indian rhino is intermediate in size.适应性强的印度犀牛是中等体型的。
This multi-skilling approach will provide the organization with an adaptable workforce.多功能技术的办法，给组织提供了一个适应性强的劳动力。

adaptation

[ˌædæp'teɪʃn], [ˌædæp'teɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 改编；改编成的作品；适应；【心】（感官）适应，适应性变化
the action or process of adapting or being adapted.
a movie, television drama, or stage play that has been adapted from a written work, typically a novel.
a change or the process of change by which an organism or species becomes better suited to its environment.
"the adaptation of teaching strategy to meet students' needs"
"filming her adaptation of a beloved children's book"
"living in groups is an adaptation that increases the efficiency of hunting"
This story lends itself to film adaptation.这个故事适合改编拍电影。
Scotish adaptation was made about a century later.大约一个世纪之后的出现了一个苏格兰的改编本。
I bought my son an adaptation for children of a play by Shakespeare.我给我儿子买了为儿童改编的莎士比亚剧本。
He made a quick adaptation to the new environment.他很快适应了新的环境。
Another idea is that art is a social adaptation.另一个想法是，艺术是一种对社会的适应。

adept

[ə'dept], [ə'dept]


Image Search
adj. 熟练的；老练的
n. 名手；专家
very skilled or proficient at something.
a person who is skilled or proficient at something.
"he is adept at cutting through red tape"
"they are adepts at kung fu and karate"
He was astonishingly adept at manipulating the big machine.他操作这台大机器熟练得惊人。
Like any culturally adept traveler, the tribe has changed its appearance throughout its history.就像任何聪明熟练的旅行老鸟，从历史上到如今这个部族一直不断地改变自己的面貌。
It may not have the best table manners, but this strange looking creature is certainly a very adept and unusual percussionist, which should help provide Nick with a good beat.也许它的吃相并不雅观，但这种相貌奇特的动物肯定是一位老练的打击乐高手，能为尼克提供一些不错的素材。
Many became adept, and thousands of fires were extinguished before they took hold.其中有很多人成了专家，几千颗烧夷弹还没有燃烧，火势头就被扑灭了。

adequate

['ædɪkwət], ['ædɪkwət]


Image Search
adj. 足够的；适当的；能胜任的
satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.
"this office is perfectly adequate for my needs"
We had adequate food for a week's journey.我们有足够的食物可以做一星期的旅行。
He sought for an adequate solution to the problem.他寻求解决这个问题的适当办法。
I hope he will be adequate to the job.我希望他将胜任这一工作。

adhere

[əd'hɪə(r)], [əd'hɪr]


Image Search
vi. 遵守；坚持；粘附
stick fast to (a surface or substance).
believe in and follow the practices of.
represent truthfully and in detail.
"paint won't adhere well to a greasy surface"
"the people adhere to the Muslim religion"
"the account adhered firmly to fact"
They failed to adhere to our original agreement.他们未能遵守我们原定的协议。
We should adhere to our opinions.我们应当坚持我们的意见。
We adhere to the principle stand of marxism.我们坚持马克思主义思想原则。
The new paint won't adhere to the walls so I'll have to strip it all off and start from scratch.新涂的油漆粘不住墙壁,因此我得把它全部刮掉,重新刷过。
Paste is used to make one surface adhere to another.糨糊是用于使一个接触面粘住另一个接触面的。

adhesive

[əd'hiːsɪv], [əd'hiːsɪv]


Image Search
adj. 有粘性的；难忘的
n. 粘着剂
able to stick fast to a surface or object; sticky.
a substance used for sticking objects or materials together; glue.
"an adhesive label"
He also invented the adhesive postage stamp.他还发明了粘性邮票。
The adhesive will stick to most clean surfaces.粘胶剂会粘在非常清洁的表面。
You need a strong adhesive to bond wood to metal.需要强力胶才能把木料粘在金属上。

adjacent

[ə'dʒeɪsnt], [ə'dʒeɪsnt]


Image Search
adj. 邻近的；毗连的；接近的
next to or adjoining something else.
(of angles) having a common vertex and a common side.
"adjacent rooms"
The house adjacent to ours has been sold.与我们家邻接的房子已经售出。
His house is adjacent to mine.他的寓所与我的相毗连。
The planes landed on adjacent runways.这些飞机在毗连的跑道上降落。
The island of Cuba is adjacent to Florida.古巴岛接近佛罗里达。
The hospital is adjacent to a church.这家医院紧挨着一座教堂。

adjustment

[ə'dʒʌstmənt], [ə'dʒʌstmənt]


Image Search
n. 调整；调节
a small alteration or movement made to achieve a desired fit, appearance, or result.
the process of adapting or becoming used to a new situation.
"I've made a few adjustments to my diet"
"for many couples there may need to be a period of adjustment"
I've made a few minor adjustments to the seating plan.我对座次表作了小小的调整。
The company made an adjustment in my salary.公司对我的薪金作了调整。
The adjustment of the interest rate will moderate.利率的调整将会放缓。
They should make adjustment to the new environment.他们应进行调整以适应新环境。
Some adjustment of the lens may be necessary.可能有必要调节一下镜头。
A small adjustment will equalize the temperature in the two rooms.稍作些调节就会使两间房内的温度相等。
The volume adjustment knob on my TV is broken.我电视机上的音量调节开关坏了。

administration

[ədˌmɪnɪ'streɪʃn], [ədˌmɪnɪ'streɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 实施；管理；行政；行政部门；任期
the process or activity of running a business, organization, etc.
the people responsible for this, regarded collectively.
the management of public affairs; government.
the management and disposal of the property of an intestate, deceased person, debtor, or other individual, or of an insolvent company, by a legally appointed administrator.
the officials in the executive branch of government under a particular chief executive.
the term of office of a political leader or government.
a government agency.
the action of dispensing, giving, or applying something.
"the day-to-day administration of the company"
"the university administration took their demands seriously"
"the inhabitants of the island voted to remain under French administration"
"the company went into administration"
"the Kennedy administration sought to use the conference to repair US prestige"
"the early years of the Reagan Administration"
"the US Food and Drug Administration"
"the oral administration of the antibiotic"
He is responsible for the administration of justice.他负责赏罚。
He works in hospital administration.他从事医院管理工作.
The company developed rapidly under his administration.在他的管理下，公司发展得很快。
Head teachers are more involved in administration than in teaching.校长的行政工作比教学工作多。
She has been looking after the, day-to-day administration.她一直在照管日常的行政工作。
I hate the prodigal administration.我痛恨铺张浪费的行政机关。
A new Presidential administration will begin soon.新一届总统任期马上就要开始了。
He tried to remedy this neglect during his own administration.他努力在他的任期内弥补这个缺陷。

admire

[əd'maɪə(r)], [əd'maɪər]


Image Search
vt. 钦佩；赞美；羡慕；欣赏
regard (an object, quality, or person) with respect or warm approval.
look at with pleasure.
"I admire your courage"
"we were just admiring your garden"
You may not like him, but you have got to admire his persistence.你可以不喜欢他，但你不得不佩服他那种坚韧不拔的精神。
We admire him for his righteousness.我们钦佩他的正直。
You had better admire others more than criticize if you want to be popular.如果你想要更受人欢迎,尽量多赞美、少批评。
Visitors admire Beijing for its beauty.观光者赞赏北京的美丽。
There is no man who does not admire him.没有人不羡慕他的。

admonish

[əd'mɒnɪʃ], [əd'mɑːnɪʃ]


Image Search
vt. 警告；训诫；告诫；提醒；敦促
warn or reprimand someone firmly.
advise or urge (someone) earnestly.
warn (someone) of something to be avoided.
"she admonished me for appearing at breakfast unshaven"
"she admonished him to drink no more than one glass of wine"
"he admonished the people against the evil of such practices"
He was admonished for his carelessness.他因粗心受到警告。
His wife admonished him not to drive too fast.他的妻子警告他开车不要超速。
He has very sternly admonished student.他十分严厉地训诫了学生。
He was admonished against doing wrong.人们告诫他不要做坏事。
I admonished him of the need for silence.我提醒他缄默的必要。

adults

[æ'dʌlts], [æ'dʌlts]


Image Search
n. 成年人；成年动物；成虫
名词adult的复数
a person who is fully grown or developed.
a fully developed animal.
a person who has reached the age of majority.
behave in a way characteristic of a responsible adult, especially by accomplishing mundane but necessary tasks.
"children should be accompanied by an adult"
"I've adulted with moderate success this week by compiling invoices and billing my client"
Some adults can't relate to children.有些成年人不理解儿童的想法。
The movie is intended for adults only.这部电影只供成年人观看。
Membership of the club is restricted to adults.本俱乐部会员仅限于成年人。
The adults are mainly herbivorous.沙蜂的成虫通常是食草性的。
Inside the nest are larva, pupa, and adults - you can eat them all.幼虫、蛹还有成虫都在蜂巢内，全都可以吃。

adversary

['ædvəsəri], ['ædvərseri]


Image Search
n. 敌手；对手
one's opponent in a contest, conflict, or dispute.
the Devil.
another term for adversarial.
"Davis beat his old adversary in the quarterfinals"
"the confrontations of adversary politics"
He set at his adversary in strong language.他以强硬的语言抨击他的敌手。
You may have a hidden adversary who would love to prove you wrong.你可能有一个潜在的敌手，他时刻准备着与你作对。
He was dismayed at the size of his adversary.对手的魁伟身材使他丧失了勇气。
They continued to view it as their major adversary.他们继续把它看作主要的对手。

adverse

['ædvɜːs], ['ædvɜːrs]


Image Search
adj. 不利的；逆向的；有害的
preventing success or development; harmful; unfavorable.
"taxes are having an adverse effect on production"
The judge gave us an adverse decision.法官作出对我们不利的判决。
He ignored all kinds of adverse comments about him.他不理睬各种各样对他不利的评论。
The development was adverse to our interests.这种发展与我们的利益背道而驰。
Diseases are adverse to the best growth of children.疾病对儿童的健康成长是有害的。

advocate

['ædvəkeɪt], ['ædvəkeɪt]


Image Search
v. 提倡；主张
n. 拥护者；提倡者；律师；辩护者
a person who publicly supports or recommends a particular cause or policy.
a person who pleads on someone else's behalf.
a pleader in a court of law; a lawyer.
publicly recommend or support.
"he was an untiring advocate of economic reform"
"care managers can become advocates for their clients"
"Marshall was a skilled advocate but a mediocre judge"
"they advocated an ethical foreign policy"
Many educators advocate a liberal education.很多教育家提倡通才教育。
We don't advocate learning by rote.死记硬背的学习方法，我们是不提倡的。
Many people advocate building more hospitals.许多人主张增设医院。
We advocate higher salaries for teachers.我们主张涨老师的工资。
She is a passionate advocate of education reform.她是一名教育改革的热情拥护者。
This judge is a strong advocate of prison reform.这位法官是监狱改革的坚决拥护者。
The advocate has undertaken my case.律师己接受我的案子。
He got the best advocate in town to defend him.他请城里最好的律师为他辩护。

affect

[ə'fekt], [ə'fekt]


Image Search
vt. 影响；感动；作用
have an effect on; make a difference to.
touch the feelings of (someone); move emotionally.
pretend to have or feel (something).
use, wear, or assume (something) pretentiously or so as to make an impression on others.
emotion or desire, especially as influencing behavior or action.
"the dampness began to affect my health"
"the atrocities he witnessed have affected him most deeply"
"as usual I affected a supreme unconcern"
"an American who had affected a British accent"
How does interest rate affect the price of bonds?利率如何影响债券的价格?
She was deeply affected by the sad story.她深深被那个悲伤的故事感动了。
His charm doesn't affect or impress me.他的魅力对我不起作用.

affiliation

[əˌfɪli'eɪʃn], [əˌfɪli'eɪʃn]


Image Search
n. 加入；入会；联系；附属机构，分公司，分部；结交，交往
the state or process of affiliating or being affiliated.
"he had no particular affiliation, no close associates"
You need the affiliation of investor.你需要投资者的加入。
The society has many affiliations throughout the country.这个社团在全国有很多关系.
Risk is always having affiliation with its impact on practice.风险总是和效用联系在一起的。
Participation in social groups in the community is independent of religious affiliation, and one's circle of friends will include people of a variety of denominations.社会上的社交团体是不管哪个教派的人都可以参加的，而一个人的社交范围包括各种教派的人。

affirm

[ə'fɜːm], [ə'fɜːrm]


Image Search
vt. 证实；断言；肯定
state as a fact; assert strongly and publicly.
declare one's support for; uphold or defend.
accept or confirm the validity of (a judgment or agreement); ratify.
make a formal declaration rather than taking an oath (e.g., to testify truthfully).
(of a court) uphold (a decision) on appeal.
offer (someone) emotional support or encouragement.
give (life) a heightened sense of value, typically through the experience of something emotionally or spiritually uplifting.
"he affirmed the country's commitment to peace"
"the referendum affirmed the republic's right to secede"
"there are five common ways parents fail to affirm their children"
"it is a rich and challenging motion picture that both affirms life and emphasizes its fragility"
Scientists cannot affirm the existence of life on other planets.科学家们还不能证实在其它星球上有生命存在。
I affirm that what he said is true.我断言他所说的是实情。
They affirmed that the girl did quite a bit of reading.他们断言这个女孩子读了不少书。
I can affirm that no one will lose their job.我可以肯定，谁都不会丢掉工作。
We are not entitled to affirm or negate anything.我们没有任何权利和资格去肯定或否定任何一件事情。

affirmative

[ə'fɜːmətɪv], [ə'fɜːrmətɪv]


Image Search
adj. 肯定的；正面的
n. 肯定词(如“yes”)；肯定语；(辩论中的)正方；赞成；肯定
agreeing with a statement or to a request.
(of a vote) expressing approval or agreement.
supportive, hopeful, or encouraging.
active or obligatory.
stating that a fact is so; making an assertion.
a statement of agreement with an assertion or request.
a position of agreement or confirmation.
a word or particle used in making assertions.
a statement asserting that something is true of the subject of a proposition.
expressing agreement with a statement or request; yes.
"an affirmative answer"
"the music's natural buoyancy and affirmative character"
"they have an affirmative duty to stop crime in their buildings"
"he accepted her reply as an affirmative"
"his answer veered toward the affirmative"
I can't give you an affirmative reply now.目前我没法给你一个肯定的答复。
"All men are mortal" is an affirmative proposition.“人总是要死的”，是一个肯定命题。
The matter is urgent. An immediate and affirmative reply is requested.事急，希即时作正面答复。
"I will" is an affirmative."我愿意"是肯定语。
They answered in the affirmative.他们作了肯定的回答。
He replied in the affirmative to my question.就我的问题他给予了肯定的回答。
The answer to both questions is in the affirmative.答案是肯定的。

affluence
