sluggish

['slʌɡɪʃ], ['slʌɡɪʃ]


Image Search
adj. 缓慢的；懒惰的；迟钝的；萧条的；无精打采的
slow-moving or inactive.
lacking energy or alertness.
slow to respond or make progress.
"a sluggish stream"
"Alex woke late feeling tired and sluggish"
"the car had been sluggish all morning"
There is a sluggish stream.那有一条流速缓慢的溪流。
The professor would try to awake their dormant and sluggish faculties.这位教授应该试图唤醒他们沉睡和懒散的天赋。
This humid heat makes you feel rather sluggish.这种湿热的天气使人感到懒洋洋的。
Some cities have been sluggish in their provision.有些城市在作出规定方面行动迟缓。
These tablets make me feel rather sluggish.我吃了这些药片感到困倦无力。

slumped

[slʌmp], [slʌmp]


Image Search
v. 大幅度下跌；猛然瘫坐；使倒下
n. 暴跌；低潮状态；(土地)下沉
sit, lean, or fall heavily and limply, especially with a bent back.
undergo a sudden severe or prolonged fall in price, value, or amount.
fail or decline substantially.
"she slumped against the cushions"
"land prices slumped"
"the Giants slumped to an 8–8 record"
Sales have slumped in the last month.上月销售量骤降。
Business slumped after the holiday.节日过后生意下降了。
She slumped, exhausted, onto the sofa.她疲惫之极地倒在沙发上
He swayed forward and slumped down in his chair.他身子向前一歪,猛地倒在靠椅里。
He slumped his lanky frame in an easy chair.他那瘦长的身躯一下子安乐椅里。
The slump hit his business hard.物价暴跌使他的生意大受打击。
There was once a slump in her career.她事业中曾出现过低谷。
The toy industry is in a slump.玩具业现在不景气。
It broke out soil slump yesterday in Guangxi province.昨天广西省发生了土崩。

smug

[smʌɡ], [smʌɡ]


Image Search
adj. 自鸣得意的；沾沾自喜的；整洁的
having or showing an excessive pride in oneself or one's achievements.
"he was feeling smug after his win"
You've got nothing to be smug about.你有什么值得自鸣得意的。
He needn't be so smug, I know something he didn't know.他用不着那么沾沾自喜，我懂得某些他不懂得的东西。

snafus

[snæ'fuː], [snæ'fuː]


Image Search
n. 混乱
adj. 混乱的
vt. 弄乱
a confused or chaotic state; a mess.
throw (a situation) into chaos.
"an enormous amount of my time was devoted to untangling snafus"
"you ignored his orders and snafued everything"
It was another bureaucratic snafu. 又让官僚主义搞成了一团糟。
Due to a police snafu, important evidence was lost. 由於警察的大谬误,主要的证据都弄丢了。
Eight hammers snafu Zhuxian town. 八锤大闹朱仙镇。
Conceivably it was a bureaucratic snafu. 这是官方的意见。
It also became synonymous with the American word "snafu. 这也就是美国人所讲的“一团糟”的意思。
Yet another snafu is plaguing this year's Academy Awards. 今年的奥斯卡奖如今又陷入困境。

snag

[snæɡ], [snæɡ]


Image Search
n. (隐伏的)障碍；困难；残桩；划破处；抽丝处
v. 划破；碰到（暗礁或枯树上）；清除（暗礁等）；迅速抓到
an unexpected or hidden obstacle or drawback.
a sharp, angular, or jagged projection.
a rent or tear in fabric caused by a sharp or jagged projection.
a dead tree.
catch or tear (something) on a projection.
become caught on a projection.
catch or obtain (someone or something).
"the picture's US release hit a snag"
"keep an emery board handy in case of nail snags"
"thorns snagged his sweater"
"radio aerials snagged on bushes and branches"
"it's the first time they've snagged the star for a photo"
The only snag could be securing a work permit.唯一的障碍只在于获得一份劳工证。
There must be a snag in it somewhere.一定是在某处出了个小故障.
The only snag is that I have no money.唯一的困难是我没钱。
A snag can provide food and a habitat for insects and birds.残株可以为昆虫和鸟类提供食物和栖息地。
I have a snag in my best black tights .我最好的一条黑裤袜给划破了。
Her tights were badly snagged.她的裤袜划破了一大片。
The river has to be snagged.必须清除这条河的暗桩。
Did you snag some tickets for us?你为我们抢到票没？

so-called

[səʊ kɔːld], [soʊ kɔːld]


Image Search
adj. <贬>号称的；所谓的
used to show that something or someone is commonly designated by the name or term specified.
used to express one's view that a name or term is inappropriate.
"next on the list are so-called “soft” chemicals like phosphorous acid"
"she could trust him more than any of her so-called friends"
There is no so-called "recipe for success".所谓“成功的诀窍”是不存在的。

solely

['səʊlli], ['soʊlli]


Image Search
adv. 独自地；单独地；完全
not involving anyone or anything else; only.
"he is solely responsible for any debts the company may incur"
He often went out solely at night.他晚上经常独自外出。
You are solely responsible for the job.这件工作由你单独负责。
I did it solely for his sake.我完全为了他才做那件事。
He was actuated solely by greed.他完全是受了贪欲的驱使。
Our quality is based solely on our sales samples.我们的质量完全以货样为准。
It was rather a shock to look into these matters and discover that the fault was solely mine.调查这些事情使我大吃一惊，我发现原来这完全是我的错。

solemn

['sɒləm], ['sɑːləm]


Image Search
adj. 庄严的；严肃的；隆重的
formal and dignified.
not cheerful or smiling; serious.
characterized by deep sincerity.
"a solemn procession"
"Tim looked very solemn"
"he swore a solemn oath to keep faith"
The ceremony proceeded in a solemn atmosphere.仪式在庄严的气氛中进行。
They watched the solemn ceremony.他们观看那庄严的仪式。
He looked at her with a solemn expression.他表情严肃地望着她。
Her solemn face told them that the news was bad.她严肃的表情告诉他们那是坏消息。
The inauguration was a solemn event.就职典礼是一件隆重的大事。
The solemn inauguration ceremony will be held here.就要举行隆重的启用仪式了。
At times solemn speeches sober down a dinner.有时庄重的发言会使宴会变得严肃起来。

solitary

['sɒlətri], ['sɑːləteri]


Image Search
adj. 孤独的；独立的；单个的；唯一的；荒凉的
n. 隐士；单独禁闭
done or existing alone.
(of a place) secluded or isolated.
single; only.
(of a bird, mammal, or insect) living alone or in pairs, especially in contrast to related social forms.
(of a flower or other part) borne singly.
a recluse or hermit.
short for solitary confinement.
"I live a pretty solitary life"
"solitary farmsteads"
"we have not a solitary shred of evidence to go on"
"a solitary wasp"
His childhood was repressed and solitary.他的童年是压抑而孤独的。
The trapper leads a solitary life in the mountains.那个设陷阱捕猎的人孤独地生活在山里。
Solitary as their lives were, is there no one person who would serve my purpose?尽管他们过的是遗世独立的生活，难道就没有一个能够对我的计划有帮助的人吗?
A solitary rider was seen in the distance.远处有个孤零零的骑马的人。
A solitary light burned dimly in the hall.大厅里点着一盏孤灯，发出昏暗的光。
She was the solitary companion of a sick father.她是病弱的父亲的唯一伴侣。
There was the solitary flat marsh on the shore.岸上是一片荒凉萧索的沼地。

soluble

['sɒljəbl], ['sɑːljəbl]


Image Search
adj. 可溶解的；可解决的
(of a substance) able to be dissolved, especially in water.
(of a problem) able to be solved.
"the poison is soluble in alcohol"
Soluble metallic hydroxides are bases that are alkalies.可溶解的金属氢氧化合物都是碱。
A subsequent wet depithing serves to remove soluble and strongly adhering pith.后续的除髓工序可以继续除去可溶解的和粘附牢固的蔗髓。

somber

['sɒmbə], ['sɒmbə]


Image Search
adj. 微暗的；阴暗的；忧郁的；严肃的；严峻的
dark or dull in color or tone; gloomy.
oppressively solemn or sober in mood; grave.
"the night skies were somber and starless"
"he looked at her with a somber expression"
She looked up staring at the somber December sky.她抬起头来，凝望着十二月份阴沉沉的天空。
His eyes were somber, resentful and yet nervous.他的眼睛显得阴沉、愤懑，然而又惶惶不安。
A funeral is a somber occasion.葬礼是个忧郁的场合。
Herzog's somber face brightened.赫索格严肃的脸上露出了笑容。
His expression was somber as he listened to the report of the accident.他听着关于事故的报告时,脸部表情严峻。

somewhat

['sʌmwɒt], ['sʌmwʌt]


Image Search
adv. 稍微；有些；多少；几分
pron. 某物；一些
to a moderate extent or by a moderate amount.
"matters have improved somewhat since then"
Their swimming pool is somewhat deep than ours.他们的游泳池比我们的游泳池稍微深一点儿。
The price was somewhat higher than I'd expected.这价格比我预料的稍高一些。
We are suffering somewhat from the heat.我们因为酷热有些不好受。
His explanation overreached somewhat.他的辩解多少有点过火。
I'm somewhat suspicious of his intentions.对他的意图我有几分怀疑。
The exact program of research we pursue will be somewhat driven by the people that we're able to attract.精确的计画研究我们追求将会是被我们能够吸引的人驱使的某物。
It was somewhat of a surprise to us.我们对此感到有点惊奇。

soothe

[suːð], [suːð]


Image Search
v. 缓和；使安静；安慰
gently calm (a person or their feelings).
reduce pain or discomfort in (a part of the body).
relieve or ease (pain).
"a shot of brandy might soothe his nerves"
"to soothe the skin try chamomile or thyme"
"it contains a mild anesthetic to soothe the pain"
He smeared some balm on his hand to soothe the pain.他在手上涂了些药膏来止痛。
He tried to soothe the crying child.他试着去哄那个在哭的孩子。
The soft texture of the blanket can soothe her.这条毯子柔软的触感可以让她安静下来。
A nice cup of tea will soothe your nerves.一杯好茶可以使你的心绪平静下来。
We did not know how to soothe the bereaved mother.我们不知如何安慰那位丧子的母亲。

sophisticated

[sə'fɪstɪkeɪtɪd], [sə'fɪstɪkeɪtɪd]


Image Search
adj. 老练的；精密的；复杂的；久经世故的
having, revealing, or proceeding from a great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture.
appealing to people with worldly knowledge or experience.
(of a machine, system, or technique) developed to a high degree of complexity.
(of a person or their thoughts, reactions, and understanding) aware of and able to interpret complex issues; subtle.
make (someone or something) more sophisticated.
talk or reason in an impressively complex and educated manner.
mislead or corrupt (a person, an argument, the mind, etc.) by sophistry.
"a chic, sophisticated woman"
"a sophisticated restaurant"
"highly sophisticated computer systems"
"discussion and reflection are necessary for a sophisticated response to a text"
"readers who have been sophisticated by modern literary practice"
"books of casuistry, which sophisticate the understanding and defile the heart"
She is such a sophisticated woman that she saw through his trick at the first sight.她是个十分老练的女人,她一眼就看穿了他的把戏。
As far as defense is concerned, we need to buy more sophisticated weapons.就防御的观点来说，我们需要购买更多精密的武器。
The publisher's techniques for the promotion of his books have become increasingly sophisticated since the 1950s.自20世纪50年代以来,出版商推销书籍的方式愈加复杂。
I'd rather deal with a simple man than a sophisticated man.我宁愿与纯朴的人打交道,不愿与世故的人交往。

sordid

['sɔːdɪd], ['sɔːrdɪd]


Image Search
adj. 卑鄙的；不诚实的；肮脏的；破烂的
involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt.
dirty or squalid.
"the story paints a sordid picture of bribes and scams"
"the overcrowded housing conditions were sordid and degrading"
He has sordid motives on us.他对我们有卑鄙的动机。
I want no part of this sordid business.我决不卷入这一卑鄙勾当。
I didn't want to hear the sordid details of their relationship.我不想听他们之间的那些龌龊细节。
The slum area was sordid and filthy beyond belief.该贫民区之污秽肮脏简直令人难以置信。
I've washed my hands of the whole sordid business.我已经彻底洗手不干那种肮脏的勾当了。
The poor family lived in a sordid hut.这个穷人家住在一个污秽的小屋里面。

sought

[sɔːt], [sɔːt]


Image Search
vbl. 搜索(seek的过去式和过去分词)
past and past participle of seek.
attempt to find (something).
attempt or desire to obtain or achieve (something).
ask for (something) from someone.
search for and find someone or something.
go to (a place).
"they came here to seek shelter from biting winter winds"
"the new regime sought his extradition"
"he sought help from the police"
"it's his job to seek out new customers"
"I sought my bedroom each night to brood over it"
We sought long and hard but found no answer.我们费力多时也未找到答案。
They sought to recover damages, costs, expenses, etc from the firm.他们设法向那家公司索取损害赔偿金、 用费、 费用等。
We sought her out to tell her of her success.我们找到她，告诉她她成功了。
This is just what I have long sought after.这就是我找寻了很久的东西。
Always he sought someone to whom he could talk without caution.他一直在找一个能够随便谈谈的人。
The government has sought an injunction preventing the paper from publishing the story.政府已经申请禁令，禁止该报发表此事。

source

[sɔːs], [sɔːrs]


Image Search
n. 来源；发源地；原始资料
v. 从...获得
a place, person, or thing from which something comes or can be obtained.
a spring or fountainhead from which a river or stream issues.
a person who provides information.
a book or document used to provide evidence in research.
a body or process by which energy or a particular component enters a system.
a part of a field-effect transistor from which carriers flow into the inter-electrode channel.
obtain from a particular source.
find out where (something) can be obtained.
"mackerel is a good source of fish oil"
"the source of the Nile"
"military sources announced a reduction in strategic nuclear weapons"
"each type of coffee is sourced from one country"
"she was called upon to source a supply of carpet"
My wages are the principal source of my income.薪金是我收入的主要来源。
Hard work is the ultimate source of success.努力工作是成功之本。
Where is the source of the Yellow River?黄河的发源地在哪儿？
The library has quantities of reference sources.该图书馆藏有大量可供参考的原始资料。
They gathered up from various sources a great amount of firsthand data.他们从各种来源搜集了大量的第一手资料。
We source all the meat sold in our stores from British farms.我们商店里卖的肉均从英国农场购进。

spaghetti

[spə'ɡeti], [spə'ɡeti]


Image Search
n. 意大利式细面条；[电]绝缘套管
pasta made in long, slender, solid strings.
an Italian dish consisting largely of this, typically with a sauce.
a type of narrow tubing that encases and insulates wire.
a tangle of stringlike objects, resembling a plate of cooked spaghetti.
"a clumsy spaghetti of coils and wires"
Spaghetti is one of my favorite foods.意大利式细面条是我喜欢的食品之一。
If you're very hungry a double helping of spaghetti should fit the bill!要是很饿的话，吃两份意大利细面条就行了！
He's a dab hand at cooking spaghetti.他是煮意大利面条的高手。

spasm

['spæzəm], ['spæzəm]


Image Search

a sudden involuntary muscular contraction or convulsive movement.
a sudden and brief spell of an activity or sensation.
prolonged involuntary muscle contraction.
experience sudden involuntary muscular contractions; twitch convulsively.
"a spasm of coughing woke him"
"the airways in the lungs go into spasm"
"my body spasmed violently"
A curious spasm passed through her.一种奇异的痉挛的感觉传遍她周身。
The spasm convulses her facial muscles.痉挛使她面部的肌肉抽搐。

spate

[speɪt], [speɪt]


Image Search
n. 泛滥；洪水；突然的一阵
a large number of similar things or events appearing or occurring in quick succession.
a sudden flood in a river, especially one caused by heavy rains or melting snow.
"a spate of attacks on travelers"
After the storm all the rivers were in spate.暴雨过后河水都上涨了。

specific

[spə'sɪfɪk], [spə'sɪfɪk]


Image Search
adj. 明确的；特殊的；具有特效的
n. 特效药；详情；特性
clearly defined or identified.
precise and clear in making statements or issuing instructions.
belonging or relating uniquely to a particular subject.
relating to or connected with species or a species.
(of a duty or a tax) levied at a fixed rate per physical unit of the thing taxed, regardless of its price.
of or denoting a number equal to the ratio of the value of some property of a given substance to the value of the same property of some other substance used as a reference, such as water, or of a vacuum, under equivalent conditions.
of or denoting a physical quantity expressed in terms of a unit mass, volume, or other measure, in order to give a value independent of the properties or scale of the particular system studied.
a medicine or remedy effective in treating a particular disease or part of the body.
a precise detail.
"increasing the electricity supply only until it met specific development needs"
"when ordering goods be specific"
"information needs are often very specific to companies and individuals"
"he worked through the specifics of the contract"
He gave us very specific instructions.他给我们做了非常明确的指示。
This tells you that there is a specific distinction between the right and the wrong.这件事告诉你是与非是有明确的区别的。
Let us take a look at three specific areas of concern.让我们看一看三个特殊的令人关切的领域。
There is no specific remedy for the malady.没有医治这种病的特效药。
This is a specific for cancer.这是一种治疗癌症的特效药。
He never talked in specifics about his work.他从不谈论有关自己工作的详情。
The specifics of this data are specified via a schema in the process definition.该数据的特性是由过程定义模式决定的。

specified

['spesɪfaɪd], ['spesɪfaɪd]


Image Search
adj. 指定的；规定的；详细说明的
identify clearly and definitely.
state a fact or requirement clearly and precisely.
include in an architect's or engineer's specifications.
"the coup leader promised an election but did not specify a date"
"the agency failed to specify that the workers were not their employees"
"naval architects specified circular portholes"
The specified system semaphore name was not found.找不到指定的系统信号灯名称。
The specified network password is not correct.指定的网络密码不正确。

speck

[spek], [spek]


Image Search
n. 斑点；灰尘；污点；少量
v. 用斑点标记
a tiny spot.
a small particle of a substance.
mark with small spots.
"the figure in the distance had become a mere speck"
"specks of dust"
"their skin was specked with goose pimples"
You can't eat bread covered with dark specks.你可不能吃满是黑斑的面包啊。
I've got a speck in my left eye.我左眼里掉进一颗灰尘。
There's not a speck of dust in their house.他们的屋里没有一点儿灰尘。
He looked at a speck on the window glass.他看着窗玻璃上的一个污点。
There is not a speck of doubt about it.那件事一点疑问也没有。
The debate aroused not a speck of public interest.这次争论没有引起公众丝毫的兴趣。

spectacle

['spektəkl], ['spektəkl]


Image Search
n. 景象；场面；奇观；壮观；公开展示；表相，假相
n. （复）眼镜
a visually striking performance or display.
an event or scene regarded in terms of its visual impact.
"the acrobatic feats make a good spectacle"
"the spectacle of a city's mass grief"
The sunrise was a splendid spectacle.日出是个壮观的景象。
The celebrations provided a magnificent spectacle.庆祝活动呈现一派宏伟的景象。
The carnival parade was a magnificent spectacle.狂欢节游行场面热烈，蔚为大观。
The children took in the spectacle open-mouthed.孩子们张着嘴注视精彩表演。
The Red Beach is a spectacle of nature.特色天成的自然奇观红海滩。
The crowd was dazzled by the spectacle.人群被这一奇观弄得眼花缭乱。
Set aside a day for the must-see spectacle of Milford Sound in the heart of NZ's unspoiled and awe-inspiring fjord-land.一定要留一天给不能错过的美景米尔福德峡湾，它位于新西兰腹地纯自然而壮观的峡湾地区。
She was a spectacle, sure enough.毫无疑问，她是丢人现眼了。
Congress is keen to avoid the spectacle of sending government workers home.国会很想避免把政府职员遣送回家的公开展示。
I can't see things through your spectacles.我和你的看法不同。
The old man put on his spectacles and started reading.老人戴上眼镜开始看书。

sphere

[sfɪə(r)], [sfɪr]


Image Search
n. 范围；领域；球；球体；天体
vt. 形成球体；包围；围绕
a round solid figure, or its surface, with every point on its surface equidistant from its center.
an object having a round solid shape; a ball or globe.
a globe representing the earth.
a celestial body.
the sky perceived as a vault upon or in which celestial bodies are represented as lying.
each of a series of revolving concentrically arranged spherical shells in which celestial bodies were formerly thought to be set in a fixed relationship.
an area of activity, interest, or expertise; a section of society or an aspect of life distinguished and unified by a particular characteristic.
enclose in or as if in a sphere.
form into a rounded or perfect whole.
denoting a structure or region of spherical form, especially a region around the earth.
denoting an area of activity, section of society, etc. distinguished by a particular characteristic.
"political reforms to match those in the economic sphere"
"ionosphere"
"blogosphere"
It belongs to the ideological sphere.这属于意识形态范围。
The scientist is distinguished in many spheres of knowledge.这位科学家在许多知识领域中都是杰出的。
Suddenly, out in the night sky, a bright sphere flashed into view.突然，外面的夜空上有一个闪光的球映入眼帘。
The earth is an oblate sphere.地球是一扁圆球体。
The earth, sun and moon are spheres.地球、太阳和月亮都是天体。

spinach

['spɪnɪtʃ], ['spɪnɪtʃ]


Image Search
n. 菠菜
a widely cultivated edible Asian plant of the goosefoot family, with large, dark green leaves that are eaten raw or cooked as a vegetable.
I do not like spinach even though I know it's good for me.尽管我知道吃菠菜对我有好处,我还是不喜欢它。
Eating spinach is supposed to make you strong.据说吃菠菜能使人强壮。
We have spinach, Chinese cabbage, onion and celery.有菠菜、大白菜、洋葱和芹菜。
You should eat such vegetables as carrot, celery and spinach.你应该吃胡萝卜、芹菜和菠菜这类的蔬菜。
Spinach with bean curd is one of my favorite dishes.菠菜豆腐是我最爱吃的一种菜。

spinning

['spɪnɪŋ], ['spɪnɪŋ]


Image Search
n. 纺纱；(用旋式诱饵)钓鱼；一种运动
动词spin的现在分词形式.
the action or process of converting fibers into thread or yarn.
an intense form of aerobic exercise performed on stationary exercise bikes and led by an instructor who sets the constantly varying pace.
turn or cause to turn or whirl around quickly.
(of a person's head) give a sensation of dizziness.
impart a revolving motion to (a ball) when bowling.
(of a ball) move through the air with a revolving motion.
give (a news story or other information) a particular interpretation, especially a favorable one.
shape (sheet metal) by pressure applied during rotation on a lathe.
draw out (wool, cotton, or other material) and convert it into threads, either by hand or with machinery.
make (threads) by drawing out and twisting fibers.
(of a spider or a silkworm or other insect) produce (gossamer or silk) or construct (a web or cocoon) by extruding a fine viscous thread from a special gland.
fish with a spinner.
"the girl spun around in alarm"
"the figures were enough to make her head spin"
"spun metal components"
"they spin wool into the yarn for weaving"
"this method is used to spin filaments from syrups"
"they were spinning for salmon in the lake"
She is unbred to spinning.她未受纺织之训练。
She is skilled at spinning and weaving.她是纺织能手。

spirited

['spɪrɪtɪd], ['spɪrɪtɪd]


Image Search
adj. 精神饱满的；生动活泼的；(用以构成复合词)情绪...的或心境...的
动词spirit的过去式和过去分词
full of energy, enthusiasm, and determination.
having a specified character, outlook on life, or mood.
convey rapidly and secretly.
"a spirited campaigner for women's rights"
"he was a warmhearted, generous-spirited man"
"stolen cows were spirited away some distance to prevent detection"
Her rich hair shaded her spirited and yet soft countenance.她那浓黑的秀发衬托着一张神采奕奕，却是柔和温存的脸蛋。
He was a very spirited, sentimental energetic boy of wide interests and talent.他生气勃勃，富有感情，精力充沛，是一个兴趣广泛而又有才能的男孩子。
Our journey was beguiled with spirited talk.我们旅行中谈笑风生，过得很愉快。
His spirited commentary made the match very interesting even on the radio.他对比赛作的实况报导十分生动，即使从收音机收听也很有趣。
The children are rather high-spirited (= excited and happy).孩子们兴高采烈。

splotch

[splɒtʃ], [splɒtʃ]


Image Search
n. 污点
vt 使 ... 有斑点
a daub, blot, or smear of something, typically a liquid.
make a daub, blot, or smear on.
"a splotch of red in a larger area of yellow"
"a rag splotched with grease"
Randomly splotch a few places at the bottom edges of your decal.在你图像底部的边缘位置，随机涂上一些污点。

spontaneous

[spɒn'teɪniəs], [spɑːn'teɪniəs]


Image Search
adj. 自发的，自然的，本能的；自然产生的
performed or occurring as a result of a sudden inner impulse or inclination and without premeditation or external stimulus.
(of a person) having an open, natural, and uninhibited manner.
(of a process or event) occurring without apparent external cause.
(of a plant) growing naturally and without being tended or cultivated.
(of movement or activity in an organism) instinctive or involuntary.
"the audience broke into spontaneous applause"
"spontaneous miscarriages"
"the spontaneous mechanical activity of circular smooth muscle"
He is spontaneous to offer help.他主动提供帮助。
It is a spontaneous cheer from the crowd.那是群众自发的喝彩。
The spontaneous applause cut the singer short.自发的掌声打断了歌唱家的演唱。
The eruption of volcanoes is spontaneous.火山爆发是自然产生的。
The spontaneous combustion of the oil-soaked rags caused the barn to catch fire.油布碎片的自燃使谷仓起火。

sporadic

[spə'rædɪk], [spə'rædɪk]


Image Search
adj. 不定时发生的；零星的
occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated.
"sporadic fighting broke out"
Primary hepatic leiomyosarcoma is very rare with only sporadic cases reported.摘要原发性肝脏平滑肌肉瘤非常少见，因此只有一些零星的病例报告。
Her only income came from sporadic leasing deals, forcing her to dip repeatedly into retirement savings.她仅有的收入来自于零星的租赁交易，这令她不得不经常动用退休储蓄。

sprawl

[sprɔːl], [sprɔːl]


Image Search
vi. 躺卧；扩张；蔓延
vt. 使蔓延
n. 躺卧；蔓延
sit, lie, or fall with one's arms and legs spread out in an ungainly or awkward way.
spread out over a large area in an untidy or irregular way.
an ungainly or carelessly relaxed position in which one's arms and legs are spread out.
a group or mass of something that has spread out in an untidy or irregular way.
the expansion of an urban or industrial area into the adjoining countryside in a way perceived to be disorganized and unattractive.
"the door shot open, sending him sprawling across the pavement"
"the town sprawled along several miles of cliff top"
"she fell into a sort of luxurious sprawl"
"a sprawl of buildings"
"the growth of urban sprawl"
Corporate sprawl distracts managers, diverts resources and muddies valuations.公司扩张吸引管理层，转移资源和扰乱估价。
By designing new neighborhoods with pedestrians in mind, they can promote slimmer lifestyles and cut down on this new kind of suburban sprawl.如果在规划设计时就能更多地考虑到步行的需要，就能促使人们采用更健康的生活方式，并遏制市郊的无限扩张。
Urban sprawl was essentially unplanned.城市蔓延是生来无计划的。
Sprawl is common in the United States.城市蔓延在美国非常普遍。
Urban sprawl was essentially unplanned.城市蔓延是生来无计划的。
Sprawl is common in the United States.城市蔓延在美国非常普遍。
Urban sprawl was essentially unplanned.城市蔓延是生来无计划的。
Sprawl is common in the United States.城市蔓延在美国非常普遍。

spying

[s'paɪɪŋ], [s'paɪɪŋ]


Image Search
间谍活动
work for a government or other organization by secretly collecting information about enemies or competitors.
observe (someone) furtively.
discern or make out, especially by careful observation.
collect information about something to use in deciding how to act.
"he agreed to spy for the West"
"the couple were spied on by reporters"
"he could spy a figure in the distance"
"he would go and spy out the land"
She's been arrested on suspicion of spying.她因涉嫌间谍活动而被捕。
The Russians think inspection is spying.俄国人认为考察就是作间谍活动。

squash

[skwɒʃ], [skwɑːʃ]


Image Search
n. 壁球；摺皱不堪；拥挤嘈杂的人群；浓缩果汁；美国南瓜
vt. 压制；压扁
vi. 变扁；挤进
crush or squeeze (something) with force so that it becomes flat, soft, or out of shape.
squeeze or force (someone or something) into a small or restricted space.
make one's way into a small or restricted space.
suppress, stifle, or subdue (a feeling, conjecture, or action).
firmly reject (an idea or suggestion).
a state of being squeezed or forced into a small or restricted space.
a sweet concentrated liquid made from or flavored with fruit juice, which is diluted to make a drink.
a game in which two players use rackets to hit a small, soft rubber ball against the walls of a closed court.
a preparation of softened tissue that has been made thin for microscopic examination by gently compressing or tapping it.
an edible gourd, the flesh of which may be cooked and eaten as a vegetable.
the trailing plant of the gourd family that produces this fruit.
"wash and squash the cans for the recycling bin"
"she squashed some of her clothes inside the bag"
"I squashed into the middle of the crowd"
"the mournful sound did nothing to squash her high spirits"
"the proposal was immediately squashed by the Historical Society"
"it was a tight squash but he didn't seem to mind"
"orange squash"
I enjoy playing tennis and squash.我喜欢打网球和壁球。
The mine reduced the car to squash.地雷把汽车炸成一堆烂铁
It's a squash with five people in this car.五个人坐在这个小汽车里太挤了。
I ordered two squashes.我要了两杯鲜果汁。
He confessed to a weakness for orange squash.他承认特别偏好柳橙。
I grow corn, tomatoes, potatoes and squash.我种玉米、西红市、土豆和南瓜。
The government was quick to squash any hopes of reform.政府很快消灭了一切改革的希望。
He sat on his hat and squashed it flat.他坐在自己的帽子上，把它压扁了。
Don't sit on my hat or you'll squash it!别坐在我的礼帽上，你会把帽子压扁了！
The fruit will squash if it is badly packed.水果如果包装不好会被压扁的。
He managed to squash into the car.他设法挤进了车子。
They squashed through the gate into the football ground.他们挤过大门，进入足球场。

squeezed

[skwiːz], [skwiːz]


Image Search
v. 挤压；塞进；压榨；设法腾出
n. 挤压；少量；拥挤；严控；财政困难
firmly press (something soft or yielding), typically with one's fingers.
extract (liquid or a soft substance) from something by compressing or twisting it firmly.
obtain (something) from someone with difficulty.
pressure (someone) in order to obtain something from them.
(especially in a financial or commercial context) have a damaging or restricting effect on.
shoot a round or shot from a gun.
take a photograph.
force (an opponent) to discard a guarding or potentially winning card.
manage to get into or through a narrow or restricted space.
manage to force into or through a narrow or restricted space.
move closer to someone or something so that one is pressed tightly against them or it.
manage to find time for someone or something.
force someone or something out of a domain or activity.
"Kate squeezed his hand affectionately"
"squeeze out as much juice as you can"
"a governor who wants to squeeze as much money out of taxpayers as he can"
"she used the opportunity to squeeze him for information"
"the economy is being squeezed by foreign debt repayments"
"squeeze off a few well-aimed shots"
"he squeezed off a half-dozen Polaroids"
"Sarah squeezed in beside her"
"she squeezed herself into her tightest pair of jeans"
"he guided her toward a seat, motioning for everyone to squeeze up and make room"
"the doctor can squeeze you in at noon"
"workers have been squeezed out of their jobs"
Kara squeezed the bottle, and the water rushed out.卡拉挤压着那个瓶子,水一下子喷了出来。
It took some ingenuity to squeeze all the furniture into the little room.把全部家具都塞进那个小房间是很费了一番心思的。
Supermarkets are accused of squeezing both customers and suppliers.超市因压榨顾客和供货商而遭到指控。
I can squeeze a meeting in early tomorrow morning.我可以在明天清早挤出时间开个会。
He gave my hand a gentle squeeze.他握着我的手,轻轻捏了捏。
The host put a squeeze of lemon in my drink.主人往我的饮料中挤了少量柠檬汁。
We managed to get all the luggage into the car but it was a tight squeeze.我们总算把行李都塞进汽车里了，不过挤得要命。
The government is putting the squeeze on business profits.政府正在对商业利润采取严格控制。
She's just lost her job, so they're really feeling the squeeze.她刚失了业，这下他们真正感到艰难了。

stagnate

[stæɡ'neɪt], ['stæɡneɪt]


Image Search
v. 停止；停滞不前；不景气
(of water or air) cease to flow or move; become stagnant.
cease developing; become inactive or dull.
"teaching can easily stagnate into a set of routines"
The one unpardonable sin of nature is to stand still, to stagnate.自然界最不可饶恕的罪行就是驻足不前，淤滞停止。
The financial industry is likely to stagnate or shrink in the next few years.今后几年，金融行业可能会停滞不前，或缩水。
If you merely repeat the same experiences you'll stagnate and your mental capacity will atrophy.假如你只重复相同的经验，就会停滞不前，脑容量会萎缩。

staid

[steɪd], [steɪd]


Image Search
adj. 固定的；（指人﹑ 外表﹑ 行为﹑ 爱好等）古板的；保守的；一本正经的
sedate, respectable, and unadventurous.
"staid law firms"
He does this by transmitting not a staid image but a simulacra.他不是通过传输固定的图像而是传输某种拟像而做到了这一点。
The museum is trying to get rid of its staid image.博物馆力图改变自己古板的形象。
I always thought of him as a rather staid old gentleman.我一直以为他是个相当古板的绅士。
The locals were a very staid lot.当地居民非常保守。
We think of the Puritans as staid people.我们认为清教徒是很稳重的人。

stall

[stɔːl], [stɔːl]


Image Search
n. 栅栏；小隔间；货摊；座位
v. 把...关进畜舍里；失速；熄火；拖延；（使）动弹不得
a stand, booth, or compartment for the sale of goods in a market or large covered area.
an individual compartment for an animal in a stable or barn, enclosed on three sides.
a stable.
a marked-out parking space for a vehicle.
a compartment for one person in a shower room, restroom, or similar facility.
a fixed seat in the choir or chancel of a church, more or less enclosed at the back and sides and often canopied, typically reserved for a particular member of the clergy.
the seats on the ground floor in a theater.
an instance of an engine, vehicle, aircraft, or boat stalling.
(of a motor vehicle or its engine) stop running, typically because of an overload on the engine.
(of an aircraft or its pilot) reach a condition where the speed is too low to allow effective operation of the controls.
have insufficient wind power in the sails to give controlled motion.
cause (an engine, vehicle, aircraft, or boat) to stall.
stop or cause to stop making progress.
speak or act in a deliberately vague way in order to gain more time to deal with a question or issue; prevaricate.
delay or divert (someone) by stalling.
put or keep (an animal) in a stall, especially in order to fatten it.
"fruit and vegetable stalls"
"speed must be maintained to avoid a stall and loss of control"
"her car stalled at the crossroads"
"his career had stalled, hers taken off"
"she was stalling for time"
"stall him until I've had time to take a look"
The excited horse flung about in the stall.受惊的马在马厩里乱冲乱踢。
The horse chafed against his stall.马在厩栏上擦著身子。
Our house has a shower stall.我们房子里有淋浴小隔间。
Never buy food from a market stall.千万别在小摊上买食物。
The opening of a market stall is governed by municipal fiat.开设市场摊位受市政法令管制。
My seat number is Row 7, Number 10 in the stall.我的座号是正厅7排10号。
You'd better stall the pigs.你最好把猪关在猪圈里饲养。
The plane stalled suddenly.那飞机突然失控下降。
If you try to start off in top gear you'll stall.要是刚一发动就用最高挡，那就会熄火。
Every time I ask her to set the date she stalls.我每次请她定一个时间，她总是借故拖延。
Stop stalling and give me an answer.别支支吾吾的了,快回答我的问题。
An inexperienced pilot can easily stall his plane.没有经验的飞行员很容易使他的飞机失速。

stamina

['stæmɪnə], ['stæmɪnə]


Image Search
n. 精力；活力；耐力
n. [植]雄蕊
名词stamen的复数形式.
the ability to sustain prolonged physical or mental effort.
"their secret is stamina rather than speed"
He doesn't have the stamina to be a teacher.他没有当教师的精力。
It's no wonder you've got so much stamina.难怪你精力这么充沛。
Currently, this region's economic development continues to maintain growth stamina.目前，该地区经济发展继续保持增长活力。
He runs every day to hone his stamina.为了增强耐力，他每天都进行跑步锻炼。
Marathon runners need plenty of stamina.参加马拉松长跑要有耐力。

statistics

[stə'tɪstɪks], [stə'tɪstɪks]


Image Search
n. 统计学；统计；统计数字
the practice or science of collecting and analyzing numerical data in large quantities, especially for the purpose of inferring proportions in a whole from those in a representative sample.
a fact or piece of data from a study of a large quantity of numerical data.
an event or person regarded as no more than a piece of data (used to suggest an inappropriately impersonal approach).
"the statistics show that the crime rate has increased"
"he was just another statistic"
He is a professor of statistics.他教授统计学。
There is a compulsory course in statistics.有一门统计学的必修课。
Get me a printout of the statistics.给我一份打印出的统计资料。
He is taking statistics.他正在进行统计。
I happen to have the official statistics with me.我碰巧身边有官方的统计数字。
Statistics should be treated with caution.对待统计数字要小心。

stature

['stætʃə(r)], ['stætʃər]


Image Search
n. 身高；名望
a person's natural height.
importance or reputation gained by ability or achievement.
"a man of short stature"
"an architect of international stature"
She was rather small in stature.她身材矮小。
He is five feet five inches in stature/height.他身高5英尺5英寸。
She had not yet grown to full stature.她的个子还没有完全长到应有的高度。
He is a musician of world stature.他是一个世界级的音乐家。
She is an artist of great stature.她是一位极具名望的艺术家。
The air weapon has now at last begun to attain its full stature.空中武器现在终于开始发挥它的充分作用了。
Time has devalued his stature as a play writer.随着时光的流逝，他作为剧作家的地位下降了。

status

['steɪtəs], ['steɪtəs]


Image Search
n. 地位；情形；状况，状态；身份
the relative social, professional, or other standing of someone or something.
high rank or social standing.
the official classification given to a person, country, or organization, determining their rights or responsibilities.
the position of affairs at a particular time, especially in political or commercial contexts.
a posting on a social networking website that indicates a user's current situation, state of mind, or opinion about something.
"an improvement in the status of women"
"those who enjoy wealth and status"
"the duchy had been elevated to the status of a principality"
"an update on the status of the bill"
"when I updated my status on Facebook yesterday I said I was 'seeking a sense of purpose'"
Women's social status has changed much over the years.这些年来妇女的社会地位有了很大改变。
I'll keep you posted on the status.我会随时告诉你进展的情形。
We ask the bank to report on his financial status.我们请银行报告他的财政状况。
There are many fine shadings of status through the social hierarchy.在各个社会等级之间有许多细微的身分区别。

steadfast

['stedfɑːst], ['stedfæst]


Image Search
adj. 坚定的；毫不动摇的
resolutely or dutifully firm and unwavering.
"steadfast loyalty"
Our nation is patient and steadfast.我们的国家是有耐心的，立场是坚定的。
He adopted a steadfast attitude towards this issue.他对这件事采取坚定的态度。
He is of a resolute and steadfast disposition.他的性格非常刚毅。

stoic

['stəʊɪk], ['stoʊɪk]


Image Search
n. 坚忍克己之人；禁欲主义者
adj. 坚忍克己的；禁欲的
Stoic.
n. 斯多葛派人士
adj. 斯多葛学派的
a person who can endure pain or hardship without showing their feelings or complaining.
a member of the ancient philosophical school of Stoicism.
another term for stoical.
of or belonging to the Stoics or their school of philosophy.
A stoic person responds to hardship with imperturbation.坚忍克己之人经受苦难仍能泰然自若。

stout

[staʊt], [staʊt]


Image Search
adj. 强壮的；肥胖的；牢固的；坚定的
n. 烈啤酒
(of a person) somewhat fat or of heavy build.
(of an object) strong and thick.
(of an act, quality, or person) brave and determined.
a kind of strong, dark beer brewed with roasted malt or barley.
"stout middle-aged men"
"Billy had armed himself with a stout stick"
"he put up a stout defense in court"
Hope is a slender reed for a stout man to lean on.希望是壮汉依靠的一根纤细的芦苇。
The stout old man waddled across the road.那粗壮的老人摇摇摆摆地穿过大路。
He became stout as he grew older.随着年龄的增长，他发胖了。
The balloon was tied down to a stout stake.气球被拴在一个结实的木桩上。
The manager put up stout resistance to the proposal.经理对提议采取坚决的抵制态度。
This stout has a slight chocolate flavor.这种烈性啤酒有点巧克力的味道。

straightforward

[ˌstreɪt'fɔːwəd], [ˌstreɪt'fɔːrwərd]


Image Search
adj. 易懂的；笔直的；坦率的
uncomplicated and easy to do or understand.
(of a person) honest and frank.
"in a straightforward case no fees will be charged"
"a straightforward young man"
The instructions are reasonably straightforward.用法说明还算简单易懂。
I wonder if the literature can be put in straightforward Chinese.我不知道那些说明书能不能译成简明易懂的中文。
This book presents an up-to-date, straightforward course for students.这本书为学生提供了一本最新式的、简明易懂的教程。
They took a straightforward route to the lake.他们走了一条笔直通向湖的路。
The straightforward and wide road has degenerated into a little path.那条宽广笔直的公路已退化成一条蹩脚的小路。
I am quite a straightforward man.我是一个非常直率的人。
His straightforward, modest manner took into camp everybody he knew.他爽直而谦虚的态度使所有认识他的人都上了当。

strand

[strænd], [strænd]


Image Search
n. 缕；(线等的)股；海滨，河岸，海滩
v. 使陷于困境；弄断；使落后；（使）搁浅
drive or leave (a boat, sailor, or sea creature) aground on a shore.
leave (someone) without the means to move from somewhere.
the shore of a sea, lake, or large river.
a single thin length of something such as thread, fiber, or wire, especially as twisted together with others.
a string of beads or pearls.
an element that forms part of a complex whole.
"the ships were stranded in shallow water"
"they were stranded in St. Louis by the blizzard"
"a heron glided to rest on a pebbly strand"
"a strand of cotton"
"certain strands of postmodern thought"
She twirled a strand of hair round her finger.她把一绺头发卷绕在手指上。
One strand of silk doesn't make a thread; one tree doesn't make a forest.单丝不成线,独木不成林。

strata

['strɑːtə], ['strɑːtə]


Image Search
n. 地层
名词stratum的复数形式.
plural form of stratum.
a layer or a series of layers of rock in the ground.
a thin layer within any structure.
a level or class to which people are assigned according to their social status, education, or income.
a group into which members of a population are divided in stratified sampling.
"a stratum of flint"
"thin strata of air"
"members of other social strata"
The older strata gradually disintegrated.年代较久的地层逐渐崩解了。
"This find is very important," he said after examining the strata.他查看了地层之后说，“这一发现很重要。”
He tried to guess how the strata behaved at the time the contortions formed.他试图推断地层在扭曲形成时是如何变化的。

strategies

['strætədʒi], ['strætədʒi]


Image Search
n. 策略；战略
a plan of action or policy designed to achieve a major or overall aim.
the art of planning and directing overall military operations and movements in a war or battle.
a plan for military operations and movements during a war or battle.
"time to develop a coherent economic strategy"
"nonprovocative defense strategies"
The strategy was designed to wear down the enemy's resistance.这一策略旨在逐步削弱敌人的抵抗力。
We will discuss our sale strategy this year.我们将讨论有关今年销售策略的问题。
He is an expert in military strategy.他是军事战略专家。
Each country needs to forge its own industrial development strategy.每个国家都需要制定自己的工业发展战略。

stratify

['strætɪfaɪ], ['strætɪfaɪ]


Image Search
v. （使）成层；分层
form or arrange into strata.
arrange or classify.
place (seeds) close together in layers in moist sand or peat to preserve them or to help them germinate.
(of seeds) be germinated by stratifying.
"socially stratified cities"
"stratifying patients into well-defined risk groups"
"if you want to sow your own mistletoe, collect ripe berries and store them in moist sand to stratify"
Stratify teaching to be one to plant in lower individual-rization collective teaching form teaching tactics.分层教学是一种在集体教学形式下的个别化教学策略。

stress

[stres], [stres]


Image Search
n. 压力；强调；重音
vt. 强调；重读
pressure or tension exerted on a material object.
the degree of pressure exerted on a material object measured in units of force per unit area.
a state of mental or emotional strain or tension resulting from adverse or very demanding circumstances.
something that causes mental strain.
physiological disturbance or damage caused to an organism by adverse circumstances.
particular emphasis or importance.
emphasis given to a particular syllable or word in speech, typically through a combination of relatively greater loudness, higher pitch, and longer duration.
give particular emphasis or importance to (a point, statement, or idea) made in speech or writing.
give emphasis to (a syllable or word) when pronouncing it.
subject to pressure or tension.
cause mental or emotional strain or tension in.
become tense or anxious; worry.
a computer programming language designed for use in solving civil engineering structural analysis problems.
"the distribution of stress is uniform across the bar"
"he's obviously under a lot of stress"
"the stresses and strains of public life"
"in many areas irrigation is warranted to avoid plant stress"
"he has started to lay greater stress on the government's role in industry"
"normally, the stress falls on the first syllable"
"they stressed the need for reform"
"this type of workout does stress the shoulder and knee joints"
"I avoid many of the things that used to stress me before"
"don't stress—there's plenty of time to get a grip on the situation"
Stress can be extremely damaging to your health.压力对你的健康会是非常有害的。
The stress on setting an example is particularly necessary at present.现在，强调以身作则这个问题很必要。
Which syllable does the stress of this word fall on?这个单词的重音是在哪个音节上?
Here I will stress the importance of mathematics to the whole of science.这里我要强调数学对整个科学的重要性。
In English, speakers can stress or emphasize words they think are important.在英语中，说话者可以重读或强调他们认为重要的单词。

an exaggeration or lie.

strident

['straɪdnt], ['straɪdnt]


Image Search
adj. 刺耳的；吱吱尖叫的；尖锐的
loud and harsh; grating.

"his voice had become increasingly sharp, almost strident"
"public pronouncements on the crisis became less strident"
His strident voice rang through the house.他那刺耳的嗓音响彻整个房子。
People are put off by her strident voice.人们对她刺耳的嗓音感到十分厌恶。
Here we can hear the strident calls of a crane or goose.这儿我们能听到一只鹤或鹅的尖锐鸣声。
The siren is really strident.警笛声好尖锐啊。
He is a strident advocate of nuclear power.他是发展核能的坚定拥护者。
The plan has provided strident criticism from local residents.这个计划招致当地居民的猛烈抨击。

strife

[straɪf], [straɪf]


Image Search
n. 争吵；冲突；倾轧；竞争
angry or bitter disagreement over fundamental issues; conflict.
"strife within the community"
She was faint with strife and dejected.她被争吵弄得精疲力竭，情绪低落。
We really shouldn't intervene in their marital strife.我们不该介入他们夫妻间的争吵。
The internecine strife was caused by a shortage of food.这次内部冲突，是由于食物匮乏而引致的。
And he remains edgy about the continuing strife in Somalia.梅莱斯也对索马里冲突不止而烦躁。
The party was rent with mutual strife.该党因互相倾轧而四分五裂。
Strife in nature is but disorder longing for order.自然界的竞争不过是混乱渴望着秩序。
Strife on college campuses helped change the attitude of the nation.高校间的竞争有助于改变国家的态度。

structural

['strʌktʃərəl], ['strʌktʃərəl]


Image Search
adj. 结构的；构造的；建筑的；建筑用的
relating to or forming part of the structure of a building or other item.
relating to the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of a complex whole.
"the blast left ten buildings with major structural damage"
"there have been structural changes in the industry"
Such structural information could be bankable.这种蛋白质结构的资讯是可以卖钱的。
The dynamic simulation of FOPS will provide the basis for the structural design.落物保护结构的动态仿真为结构的设计提供了依据。
Note that in areas of monoclinal dip the closure of a trap may not be the same as its structural relief.值得注意的是，在只有单斜地层的构造内，圈闭的幅度可能与构造的起伏不一样。
Interpretation of these structures can be improved by the application of accurate structural models and balanced cross section techniques.利用准确的构造模型的平衡截面兔方法能提高对这些构造的解释。
Blue fluorescent tubes wash the floor with an eerie light while up-lighters accentuate structural members.蓝色的荧光灯管给地板渡上了一层奇特的光亮，向上照射的灯渲染着建筑的每一部分。
The structural type and design scheme for a building project should be based on its serviceable function and force conditions.摘要建筑工程设计时，需要根据建筑的使用功能和建筑结构的受力特征，确定结构形式及设计方案。

structure

['strʌktʃə(r)], ['strʌktʃər]


Image Search
n. 结构；构造；建筑物
vt. 构造；建造；组织
the arrangement of and relations between the parts or elements of something complex.
a building or other object constructed from several parts.
the quality of being organized.
construct or arrange according to a plan; give a pattern or organization to.
"flint is extremely hard, like diamond, which has a similar structure"
"we shall use three headings to give some structure to the discussion"
"the game is structured so that there are five ways to win"
Can you analyze the structure of the sentence for me?你能给我分析一下这个句子的结构吗？
Most linguists would say they were concerned primarily with the structure of languages.大多数语言学家都会说，他们主要研究各种语言的结构。
We learnt about the structure of the brain today.今天我们学习了大脑的构造。
The structure had keeled over in the high winds.那座建筑物让大风给刮倒了。
We learnt about the structure of the brain today.今天我们学习了大脑的构造。
Muscle structure and reflex arcs.肌肉构造和反射弧。
The structure filled 29 acres -- enough space to accomodate five U.S.五角大楼的设计为战争年代节约了建造一座战舰的钢材。
It is thought to have been the planet's tallest human-made structure for more than four millennia.在四千万年的历史长河中，它被认为是地球上由人类建造的最高的建筑。
You need to structure your arguments more carefully.你需要更为仔细地组织自己的论点。

submissive

submitted

Image Search

vi. 屈从
accept or yield to a superior force or to the authority or will of another person.

subject to a particular process, treatment, or condition.
consent to undergo a certain treatment.
present (a proposal, application, or other document) to a person or body for consideration or judgment.

"the original settlers were forced to submit to Bulgarian rule"
"the U.S. refused to submit to arbitration"
"samples submitted to low pressure"
"he submitted himself to a body search"
